subject: RE: [junit] novice QA
msgSnippet: A couple of brute force ideas... Is there any reason not to open up the vector to the client and allow the client to decide what to do with it?  You can still
messageBody:
A couple of brute force ideas...

Is there any reason not to open up the vector to the client and allow the
client to decide what to do with it? You can still have the print method
that will format the contents of the vector for you.

If you don't want to open up the vector, how about passing in a printstream
to the print method? That way you could test that the stream contains
everything you expect it to have.

FYI: There is overhead in Vector that probably isn't needed in your class --
you should be using a List (i.e. ArrayList).

-Jason

> -----Original Message-----
> From: the_shark_tank@... [mailto:the_shark_tank@...]
> Sent: Monday, August 06, 2001 3:45 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] novice QA
>
>
> Hello All!
>
> I am invading your group as a mere QA intern. . . I am
> supposed to
> implement junit tests on code that I have just written.
> However, what
> I have learned in school does not seem to apply here! We learned
> that if the method is an "add" method, give it two numbers,
> and "assert" that the corrent addition is performed, and
> so on. . .
> well, I have no clue what to assert!
>
> Quick rundown of what I am testing:
>
> Basically, my code is using the Reflection class to check all the
> members of a class for a certain type of compatibility.
> Most methods
> add errors to an error vector, and then there is a simple print
> function to print out the vector... How on earth do I test this
> class??
>
> Thanks for any help in advance!!
>
> Yours truly,
> The Shark
